an5.110:4.1: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has four qualities they’re ready to frequent remote wilderness and jungle lodgings.
an5.110:4.3: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the code of conduct, and has appropriate behavior and means of collecting alms. Seeing danger in the slightest flaw, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an5.110:4.4: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and understanding them with right view.
an5.110:4.5: They live with energy roused up for giving up unwholesome qualities and gaining wholesome qualities. They’re strong, firmly applied, not slacking off when it comes to developing wholesome qualities.
an5.110:4.6: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
an5.110:4.7: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having achieved it with their own insight due to the end of defilements.
an5.110:4.8: When a mendicant has these four qualities they’re ready to frequent remote wilderness and jungle lodgings.”
